@GretaThunberg @TheDisproof @penguinpress Congrats 👏🏻👏🏻👏🏻
@edwindiender Right? It was a bit frustrating, but hilarious at the same time
@PaulSweeney See for yourself if it is worth it. It definitely is for me, but trying it out only sets you back €20

@xoxo_YolandaW @MarketerNCust You can always set up a new account, sign up for the Plus version, compare it with your free version and if you don’t think it’s good enough, cancel the subscription and the test has cost you $20. That’s what I did and was blown away by how much better it was for my use case
@xoxo_YolandaW Anytime 👍🏻
@markkorthuis I like to give it lots of text (6,000 words or more) and then ask it loads of questions about the text

@thisisjeffchen You can input far more text in your questions and it maintains the state for far longer (you can continue asking questions). The free version was like this back in Dec but started to deteriorate as more people started to use it
I signed up for #ChatGPT Plus, and let me tell you, for my use case, it is orders of magnitude better than the free version. https://t.co/0VccIbB94C
@josheac Ha! I'll try that one later and let you know how I get on!

My 5 key takeaways from this episode:

Overall, it was an enlightening conversation and I believe our listeners will find it incredibly valuable. I encourage you to give it a listen and let me know your thoughts.

We also touched on the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the supply chain and the ways in which it has accelerated the adoption of digital solutions. Greg shared his thoughts on how the industry will continue to evolve post-pandemic and the opportunities that lie ahead.
He also highlighted the importance of data and analytics in making informed decisions and staying ahead of the competition.

Another highlight of our conversation was the discussion on the role of technology in the supply chain. Greg shared insights on how Shipwell is using cutting-edge technology to streamline operations and improve efficiency for their clients.
Greg emphasized that in times of economic uncertainty and recession, it's crucial to take a step back and look at the bigger picture in order to identify opportunities and drive positive outcomes.
One of the key takeaways from our conversation was the importance of strong leadership in navigating the uncertain and rapidly-changing landscape of the industry.

If you're interested in learning more about sustainable farming and the role of technology in reducing emissions, be sure to listen to this episode and follow the Climate Confident podcast for more updates and discussions on this and all Climate topics.
Overall, this episode provides valuable insights into how technology and sustainable practices can benefit both farmers and the environment.

Robin mentioned how some food companies are starting to offer a premium for food grown with lower emissions, and how some land owners are offering reduced rental rates to farmers who adopt sustainable practices.
Another interesting topic we discussed is the role of food companies and land owners in promoting sustainable farming.
He also touched on the benefits farmers can receive by implementing sustainable practices, such as carbon credit income and sustainable loans with lower interest rates.

One of the key takeaways from the episode is the importance of precision in farming. Robin explains how precision fertilization and precision farming can lead to more efficient use of resources, and ultimately lower emissions.
But as time passed, the tool evolved to include carbon and greenhouse gas tracking, as it's crucial for farmers to consider the environmental impact of their decisions.

Robin shared with us how his family's organic grain farm in Estonia prompted him to develop eAgronom, a tool for farmers to manage their operations, including financial reporting and people management.
In this episode, we delve into the world of sustainable farming and how technology can play a vital role in reducing emissions in the agricultural industry.
In this latest episode, I had the pleasure of speaking with Robin Saluoks (https://t.co/rFgAF8ifKp), CEO of eAgronom (https://t.co/kc7romylzK).

This is why it's so important to have a conversation about sustainable and responsible agricultural practices, and that's exactly what the latest episode of my Climate Confident podcast (https://t.co/uo5dntM82O) aims to do.

Agriculture is one of the most critical industries when it comes to climate change. Not only does it play a major role in producing the food we rely on, but it also impacts our environment and natural resources in countless ways.

Climate Solutions on the Farm: How eAgronom’s platform is revolutionising sustainable agriculture

If you're interested in learning more about the company or connecting with Tim, you can visit their website at https://t.co/cDwPGLxf2r or find him on LinkedIn (https://t.co/plZlgYb4sW).

The conversation with Tim was both informative and inspiring. It's clear that Tradewater is making a significant impact in the fight against climate change, and I encourage listeners to check out the full episode to learn more about the work that they are doing.
The global nature of this work highlights the magnitude of this problem, but it also presents an opportunity to work in a global context and bring this work up to scale.
One of the key takeaways from the podcast is that these gases are fungible in the atmosphere and collecting, controlling, and destroying them will benefit everyone.
…evaluate about 16 more countries this year.

They are always looking for partners and people who are knowledgeable about where these gases may exist, and they have done projects and are working in Honduras, Dominican Republic, Chile, Saudi Arabia, UAE, Bahrain, Zimbabwe, Egypt, Thailand and also have intentions to…
Tim also shared that one of the most interesting aspects of their work has been the global dimension of it and how it has put them in contact with many interesting people around the world.
Trade Water's current goal is to reach a new baseline of 3 million metric tons per year, starting in 2023 and by 2028, they hope to have done 20 million tons of impact.
…insulation, and other applications. On the HCFCs, which are lower in their global warming potential emissions factor, there are 5 billion metric tons of those gases deployed around the world.

Tim also discussed the scale of the issue, with researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology recently estimating that there are 9 billion metric tons of CO2 equivalent from these gases scattered around the world, most of them already in appliances, foams, building…

The gases that Tradewater is currently focusing on include old refrigerants that are up to 10,900 times as potent as CO2, and methane from abandoned and orphaned oil and gas wells that are leaking methane into the atmosphere.

During the podcast, Tim explains that as a mission-driven company, Tradewater is particularly interested in non-CO2 gases, which are short-lived climate pollutants that do their damage early on when they are released.
Tradewater is a company that is focused on collecting, controlling, and destroying greenhouse gases with the goal of making the biggest impact possible, as fast as possible.
The latest episode of my Climate Confident Podcast (https://t.co/J1tzhVTR4i) features a conversation with Tim Brown (https://t.co/plZlgYb4sW), the CEO of Tradewater (https://t.co/tmQvJTKaHJ).

#Climate Solutions in Action: An In-Depth Look at Tradewater's Efforts to Combat #GreenhouseGases

Overall, the SBTI is a powerful and innovative organization that is making a real difference in the fight against climate change. I encourage all businesses to get involved and make use of the resources and support the SBTI has to offer.
This ensures that companies are held accountable and are making progress towards their ambitious goals.

Lastly, the SBTI has a robust accountability system in place. Companies are required to resubmit their targets every five years and reevaluate their progress. In addition, the SBTI also conducts third-party assessments based on public information.
This makes the SBTI accessible to companies of all sizes and locations.

Another great thing about the SBTI is that it is a not-for-profit organization. While there is a fee for submitting and validating targets, the real financial decision-making comes from developing and implementing a plan.
This comprehensive approach is crucial in the fight against climate change.

One of the things that I found most fascinating about the SBTI is their use of the Greenhouse Gas Protocol guidelines. This means that the SBTI takes into account other gases besides carbon, such as methane, in determining emissions reductions targets.

The SBTI was born out of a realization that there needed to be a way to standardize what "good" looks like for corporate climate action, so that progress could be evaluated and compared. The organization's goal is to support companies on their path towards a net zero future.
It's a truly innovative partnership between several organizations, including the United Nations Global Compact, WWF, World Resources Institute, CDP and Women in Business Coalition.
The SBTI is a global body that works to enable businesses to set ambitious emissions reductions targets that align with what climate science tells us is necessary.

In my latest episode of the Climate Confident podcast (https://t.co/DlWiKPFdde), I had the pleasure of interviewing Luiz Amaral (https://t.co/k7LsY4rbBu), the CEO of the Science-Based Targets Initiative (https://t.co/BY0gEOCyCb) (SBTI).

The Ultimate Guide to Corporate Climate Action: The Science-Based Targets Initiative
